children.subject: As an international student, you can only work part-time during the semester. If you withdraw, your only option is to use your OPT.

history.content:
I can’t speak to anything regarding international work visas and similar, but I interned part-time for the entirety of my college career. I would NOT recommend doing a full-time internship and school. You will be working 40/hrs a week and taking early morning/late at night classes. Just part-time was incredibly draining and took extensive time management and sacrifices. I’m sure it’s possible, but it’s probably not the best idea unless it’s a situation where you have no choice—e.g. you have to work to pay for school. Working part-time would be a better option; school is more feasible. I found it incredibly rewarding and I learned a lot. But be prepared to sacrifice a good deal of time. 

If you choose to go that route, you should schedule a meeting with your advisor as soon as possible. Readmission after withdrawal is not automatic, and I have no idea what the processes are for an international student. There are also requirements, specific to college and department, regarding what you may take in a term. You may not be able to take all PNP classes. You may also be able to petition for a reduced course load for reason of employment, but usually they require you to prove financial need to work. And, it may be different for international students. 

If if you have more specific questions about what it’s like to intern while attending classes, feel free to reach out. I should still be in the student directory.

Has anyone gotten a full-time internship during a semester, say during fall? I'm wondering how that works in terms of school. Would it be possible to get all PNP breadths or perhaps withdraw for a semester? Also, as an international student, can I still use CPT if I withdraw?
